Sorry, but sonograms can be off by up to 3 lbs. blueeyedtabbycat just delivered a little 7 lb baby when she was told her daughter would be well over 9 lbs.Also, 34 weeks is WAY TOO EARLY to induce. No doctor would ever do that. Despite how big they think baby may be, their lungs still need to develop or you're going to have a baby in the NICU, with possible long-term problems (asthma, for example).

Well blueyedtabycat (sp?) just had her baby, was told her baby was 9lb 11oz a week  or so before devliering and her baby weighed 7lbs some oz!  So the u/s was obviosuly wrong.  According to my doctor, the later you are in pregnancy the less accurate the u/s can be.  I know my baby measured anywhere from 2-4 weeks ahead of schedule during my 31 week u/s.  She was 8lb 9oz at birth (doctor estimated 9-10lb).  And I was induced due to mild preeclampsia (I was very swollen also).  The thing is, most doctors won't do any inducing until at least 36 weeks because the babies lungs (and other parts) aren't fully developed.  Even though your baby measures 38 weeks, that doesn't mean everything is fully developed and I don't think any doctor would want to bring out a baby earlier than 36 weeks unless there is a medical emergency.  I don't even think it's medically possible for your baby to double it's weight in a month (then again I'm not a doctor) - 14lbs seems like waaaaay to big - we'd probably hear about you in the news if that was the case, LOL!  I would definitly get a second opinion though.
